text:
Great to hear from you Salam ! 
I was worried when I got into games and Vfx about the working hours etc. And I think it's healthy to have that worrying , but when you are in it it doesn't feel that bad. And it's in your control , no one can force you to work too many hours if you don't want to. 
It does depend on where you work and what part of the project you are in , also what job you do in the chain ( comp , editorial , production and audio mostly need to wait for other teams to finish before they can finish so they tend to get hit by the late nights and weekends.
There are a lot of people who choose to work late because they want to sleep in , at FS these people get free dinner :) so even though they appear to work loads they are not doing much more than others.
More jr people think they need to work really long hours to impress and progress , but I know lots of senior managers who see the person working late as being someone who doesn't work efficiently . And setting expectations that others need to do the same , which can make these people working long hours unpopular ;).
The industry we are in , we don't save any lives , so we don't need to stress too much.
If you work hard and focus during the day you should not need to crunch much. 
And it's important you have a life too.

Thank you for such a detailed answer, that really explains a lot. When I was at FS, the recruitment officer mentioned that a very last minute change had to be made on a certain film 3 months before the release date. She said that most people who took all nighters etc took a couple months off of work. Isn't it a bit worrying to not have a regular source of income when you're working in short bursts like that.
